member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.MD5Managed
member.summary: MD5Managed: A HashAlgorithm implementation that acts as a thin wrapper around a C# translation of the MD5 reference implementation. The C code has been translated as closely as possible so that most of the original structure remains and comparisons between the two are straightforward.
member.remarks:
Derived from the RSA Data Security, Inc. MD5 Message-Digest Algorithm.
Specification: RFC1321 - The MD5 Message-Digest Algorithm http://www.faqs.org/rfcs/rfc1321.html
Original license: Copyright (C) 1991-2, RSA Data Security, Inc. Created 1991. All rights reserved.
License to copy and use this software is granted provided that it is identified as the "RSA Data Security, Inc. MD5 Message-Digest Algorithm" in all material mentioning or referencing this software or this function.
License is also granted to make and use derivative works provided that such works are identified as "derived from the RSA Data Security, Inc. MD5 Message-Digest Algorithm" in all material mentioning or referencing the derived work.
RSA Data Security, Inc. makes no representations concerning either the merchantability of this software or the suitability of this software for any particular purpose. It is provided "as is" without express or implied warranty of any kind.
These notices must be retained in any copies of any part of this documentation and/or software.

member.summary: Read data from the stream.

remarks.para: To decompress a BZip2 data stream, create a BZip2InputStream, providing a stream that reads compressed data. Then call Read() on that BZip2InputStream, and the data read will be decompressed as you read.
A BZip2InputStream can be used only for Read(), not for Write().

member.param: The buffer into which the read data should be placed.
the offset within that data array to put the first byte read.
the number of bytes to read.
member.returns: the number of bytes actually read

member.summary: Indicates that the socket encountered an error while sending.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.SocketReceiveError
member.summary: Indicates that the socket encountered an error while receiving.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.SocketClosed
member.summary: Indicates that the socket is closed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.SocketSendBufferFull
member.summary: Indicates that the socket's send buffer is full.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.IPProtocolMismatch
member.summary: Indicates the IP Protocol mismatch has occurred.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.PacketTooLarge
member.summary: Indicates the supplied Turn relay server is invalid or not resolved.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTryAlternate
member.summary: 300 Try Alternate. RFC5389. Indicates that a server using this extension redirects a client to another server by replying to a request message with an error response message with an error code of 300 (Try Alternate). The server MUST include an ALTERNATE-SERVER attribute in the error response. The error response message MAY be authenticated; however, there are uses cases for ALTERNATE-SERVER where authentication of the response is not possible or practical.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunBadRequest
member.summary: 400 Bad Request. RFC5389. Idicates that the original request was malformed. The client SHOULD NOT retry the request without modification from the previous attempt. The server may not be able to generate a valid MESSAGE-INTEGRITY for this error, so the client MUST NOT expect a valid MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute on this response.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunUnauthorized
member.summary: 401 Unauthorized. RFC5389. Indicates that the request did not contain the correct credentials to proceed. The client should retry the request with proper credentials.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnForbidden
member.summary: 403 Forbidden. RFC 5766. Indicates that the request is valid, but the server is refusing to perform it, likely due to administrative restrictions. The client considers the current transaction as having failed. The client MAY notify the user or operator and SHOULD NOT retry the same request with this server until it believes the problem has been fixed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnMobilityForbidden
member.summary: 405 Mobility Forbidden. RFC 8016. Indicates that the request is valid, but the server is refusing to perform it, likely due to administrative restrictions. The client considers the current transaction as having failed. The client can notify the user or operator. The client SHOULD NOT retry sending the Allocate request containing the MOBILITY-TICKET with this server until it believes the problem has been fixed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunUnknownAttribute
member.summary: 420 Unknown Attribute. RFC5389. Indicates that the server received a STUN packet containing a comprehension-required attribute that it did not understand. The server MUST put this unknown attribute in the UNKNOWN-ATTRIBUTE attribute of its error response.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunStaleCredentials
member.summary: 430 Stale credentials; the shared secret sent in the request is expired; the client should obtain a new shared secret.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunIntegrityCheckFailure
member.summary: 431 Integrity Check Failure.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunMissingUsername
member.summary: 432 Missing Username; the username attribute is not present in the request.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnAllocationMismatch
member.summary: 437 Allocation Mismatch. RFC 5766. This indicates that the client has picked a 5-tuple that the server sees as already in use. One way this could happen is if an intervening NAT assigned a mapped transport address that was used by another client that recently crashed. The client considers the current transaction as having failed. The client SHOULD pick another client transport address and retry the Allocate request (using a different transaction id). The client SHOULD try three different client transport addresses before giving up on this server.Once the client gives up on the server, it SHOULD NOT try to create another allocation on the server for 2 minutes.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunStaleNonce
member.summary: 438 Stale Nonce. RFC5389. Indicates that the NONCE used by the client was no longer valid. The client should retry, using the NONCE provided in the response.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunAddressFamilyNotSupported
member.summary: 440 Address Family Not Supported. RFC 6156. Indicates that the server does not support the address family requested by the client.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnWrongCredentials
member.summary: 441 Wrong Credentials. RFC 5766. Indicates that wrong credential were used by the client. The client should not receive this error in response to an Allocate request. The client MAY notify the user or operator and SHOULD NOT retry the same request with this server until it believes the problem has been fixed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnUnsupportedTransportProtocol
member.summary: 442 Unsupported Transport Protocol. The client should not receive this error in response to a request for a UDP allocation. The client MAY notify the user or operator and SHOULD NOT reattempt the request with this server until it believes the problem has been fixed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnPeerAddressFamilyMismatch
member.summary: 443 Peer Address Family Mismatch. A peer address was of a different address family than that of the relayed transport address of the allocation.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnConnectionAlreadyExists
member.summary: 446 Connection Already exists. This indicates that either 1) the server is currently processing a Connect request for this allocation with the same XOR-PEER-ADDRESS; OR 2) the server has already successfully processed a Connect request for this allocation with the same XOR-PEER-ADDRESS, and the resulting client and peer data connections are either pending or active

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnConnectionTimeoutOrFailure
member.summary: 447 Connection Timeout or Failure. This indicates that the TURN server was unable to connect to the peer. The client MAY retry with the same XOR-PEER-ADDRESS attribute, but MUST wait at least 10 seconds.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnAllocationQuotaReached
member.summary: 486 Allocation Quota Reached. The server is currently unable to create any more allocations with this username. The client considers the current transaction as having failed. The client SHOULD wait at least 1 minute before trying to create any more allocations on the server.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunIceRoleConflict
member.summary: 487 Role Conflict. The Binding request contained either the ICE-CONTROLLING or ICE-CONTROLLED attribute, indicating a role that conflicted with the server. The server ran a tie-breaker based on the tie-breaker value in the request and determined that the client needs to switch roles.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunServerError
member.summary: 500 Server Error. RFC5389. Indicates that the server has suffered a temporary error. The client should try again.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunTurnInsufficientCapacity
member.summary: 508 Insufficient Capacity. The server has no more relayed transport addresses available, or has none with the requested properties, or the one that was reserved is no longer available. The client considers the current operation as having failed. If the client is using either the EVEN-PORT or the RESERVATION-TOKEN attribute, then the client MAY choose to remove or modify this attribute and try again immediately. Otherwise, the client SHOULD wait at least 1 minute before trying to create any more allocations on this server.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunInvalidResponseType
member.summary: Indicates Invalid Response Type, where message type obtained in reponse to a request is of unexpected type.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.ErrorCode.StunInvalidErrorCode
member.summary: Indicates that a failed response does not contain an error code or when the error code is inconsistent with the contents of the response.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol
member.summary: Utility class to assist with Network Time Protocol (NTP) conversions. NTP timestamps are 64-bit values that can span just over 136 years, from 1900-01-01 to 2036-02-08. Compact NTP timestamps are 32-bit values that can span span just over 18 hours. These utility methods guarantee precision to the millisecond.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.UtcNow
member.summary: Gets the current UTC time in NTP format.

member.summary: Converts a date to an NTP timestamp (double).

member.summary: Converts an NTP timestamp (double) to a date.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.TicksToNtpSeconds(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts ticks to an NTP timestamp (double).

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.NtpSecondsToTicks(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts an NTP timestamp (double) to ticks.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.DateTimeToNtp(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Converts a date to an NTP timestamp (64 bits).

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.NtpToDateTime(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts an NTP timestamp (64 bits) to a date.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.TicksToNtp(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts ticks to an NTP timestamp (64 bits).

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.NtpToTicks(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts an NTP timestamp (64 bits) to ticks.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.DateTimeToCompactNtp(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Converts a date to a compact NTP timestamp (32 bits).

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.CompactNtpToDateTime(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts a compact NTP timestamp (32 bits) to a date.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.TicksToCompactNtp(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts ticks to a compact NTP timestamp (32 bits).

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.NetworkTimeProtocol.CompactNtpToTicks(System.Int64)
member.summary: Converts a compact NTP timestamp (32 bits) to ticks.

member.summary: Only suitable for development use, probability of failure may be greater than 1/2^20.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor.Low
member.summary: Suitable only for transactions which do not require forward secrecy. Probability of failure about 1/2^40

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor.Medium
member.summary: Designed for production use. Probability of failure about 1/2^80.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor.High
member.summary: Suitable for sensitive data. Probability of failure about 1/2^160.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor.ExtraHigh
member.summary: Use only if you have lots of time! Probability of failure about 1/2^320.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor.Provable
member.summary: Only use methods which generate provable primes. Not yet implemented.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.PrimalityTests.RabinMillerTest(FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger,FM.LiveSwitch.BigInteger.ConfidenceFactor)
member.summary: Probabilistic prime test based on Rabin-Miller's test

param.name: confidence
param.para: The number of chosen bases. The test has at least a 1/4^confidence chance of falsely returning True.

returns.para: True if "this" is a strong pseudoprime to randomly chosen bases.
False if "this" is definitely NOT prime.

member.param: A BigInteger that has been subjected to and passed trial division
member.returns: False if bi is composite, true if it may be prime.
member.remarks: The speed of this method is dependent on Confidence

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode
member.summary: An enumeration of potential WebSocket status codes.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.Normal
member.summary: Indicates normal closure, meaning that the purpose for which the connection was established has been fulfilled.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.GoingAway
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is "going away", such as a server going down or a browser having navigated away from a page.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.ProtocolError
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is terminating the connection due to a protocol error.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.InvalidType
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is terminating the connection because it has received a type of data that it cannot accept.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.NoStatus
member.summary: Indicates that no status code was present in the Close frame. Reserved for use outside Close frames.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.Abnormal
member.summary: Indicates that the connection was closed abnormally, without sending a Close frame. Reserved for use outside Close frames.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.InvalidData
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is terminating the connection because it has received data within a message that was not consistent with the type of message.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.PolicyViolation
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is terminating the connection because it has received a message that violates its policy.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.MessageTooLarge
member.summary: Indicates that an endpoint is terminating the connection because it has received a message that is too big for it to process.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.UnsupportedExtension
member.summary: Indicates that the client is terminating the connection because it has expected the server to negotiate one or more extensions, but the server didn't return them in the response message of the WebSocket handshake.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.UnexpectedCondition
member.summary: Indicates that the server is terminating the connection because it encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.WebSocketStatusCode.SecureHandshakeFailure
member.summary: Indicates that the connection was closed due to a failure to perform a TLS handshake. Reserved for use outside Close frames.

member.summary: Gets or sets the original arguments passed to the open method.

member.summary: Gets or sets the exception generated by the active connection.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.TargetedScan
member.summary: Defines how the server scans referenced assemblies to locate event and script modifier methods that may be part of the application code or an extension.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.TargetedScan.Auto
member.summary: Instructs the server to exclude referenced assemblies that match a pre-defined black-list of Microsoft, Windows, and Frozen Mountain assemblies (this is the default).

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.TargetedScan.Off
member.summary: Instructs the server to scan every referenced assembly.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.TargetedScan.On
member.summary: Instructs the server to only include referenced assemblies that define the assembly-level attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig
member.summary: Server configuration properties.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.ProviderType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of the signalling provider. Defaults to FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.InProcProvider.
member.value: The type of the signalling provider.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.Timeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval between checks to see if a client is still active or can be considered idle. Defaults to 25000 (ms).
member.value: The timeout period during which a client stream request can gather messages.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.LatencyBuffer
member.summary: Gets or sets the latency buffer which allots "grace" periods of time for high-latency clients. Lower values will increase the rate at which old clients and messages are cleaned up at the risk of missed messages or removed client records for slow clients. Higher values offer higher reliability with potential performance costs. Defaults to 10000 (ms).

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.ReconnectInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the interval a client should allow between a completed server response and a new client request. This applies to clients that use the long-polling connection type. Defaults to 0 (ms).
member.value: The interval between a stream message received by the client and its next request.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.DistributeInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets interval between distributions of messages to respective clients. Defaults to 10 (ms).
member.value: The interval between distributions of messages to respective clients.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Configuration.ServerConfig.HeartbeatInterval

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Pool`1.Acquire
member.summary: Acquires an object from the pool. If there are no available objects, a new object is created provided there is no maximum size constraint or the number of objects in the pool is less than the maximum size. If there are no available objects and the maximum size of the pool has been reached, then this method will block until an object can be acquired.
member.returns: The item acquired from the pool.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SessionAccessLevel
member.summary: The level of session-state access being used.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SessionAccessLevel.None
member.summary: Indicates that session-state data is unavailable. Handlers with this value do not acquire a lock on the session. They will not block or be blocked by other handlers, regardless of their access level.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SessionAccessLevel.ReadOnly
member.summary: Indicates that session-state data is available for reading, but not writing. Handlers with this value acquire a shared read lock on the session for the duration of the request being processed. They will not block or be blocked by other handlers with the same access. However, they will block and be blocked by handlers with access, since those handlers require an exclusive lock.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SessionAccessLevel.ReadWrite
member.summary: Indicates that session-state data is available for reading and writing. Handlers with this value acquire an exclusive read/write lock on the session for the duration of the request being processed. They will block and be blocked by other handlers with the either or the same access.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode
member.summary:
Defines all possible error codes used in signalling. Error codes are grouped into 4 categories:
600-level: indicate that the request could not be started
700-level: indicate that a provider error occurred while the request was processing
800-level: indicate that the request was denied by an event handler
900-level: indicate that an internal server error occurred when processing the request

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.DeserializationFailure
member.summary: This error occurs when the message and/or publication sent to signalling was invalid JSON.
member.remarks: The error text is: 601::Could not deserialize incoming messages or publications.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.EmptyRequest
member.summary: This error occurs when signalling receives an empty POST or GET request.
member.remarks: The error text is: 602::Incoming request was empty.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoClientId
member.summary: This error indicates that no client ID was specified in the request.
member.remarks: The error text is: 603::No client ID.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.ClientDoesNotExist
member.summary: This error indicates that the client ID, stream ID, and auth token specified in the request do not represent a valid client record on the server. This can occur if 1) the server was reset and lost all its client information or 2) the client passed an invalid client ID, stream ID, and/or auth token after awakening from standby or some other client failure. This error is expected occasionally under normal use.
member.remarks: The error text is: 604::Client does not exist.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoStreamId
member.summary: This error indicates that no stream ID was specified in the request.
member.remarks: The error text is: 605::No stream ID.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoAuthToken
member.summary: This error indicates that no auth token was specified in the request.
member.remarks: The error text is: 606::No auth token.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.PublisherNotAllowed
member.summary: This error occurs when a publisher attempts to interact with a signalling server, but publisher access has been disabled. To enable publisher access, edit your Web.configs allowPublishers entry as described in Security.
member.remarks: The error text is: 608::HTTP publication is disabled. Check your web.config settings.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoRequestHandler
member.summary: This error occurs when the request handler failed to initialize. Typically, this results from an incorrectly configured web.config, such as missing handlers, invalid types for the handlers, etc. If logging is configured, there will be additional details available in your logs.
member.remarks: The error text is: 609::The request handler could not be initialized. Check your web.config settings and logs.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoThreadPool
member.summary: This error occurs when the thread pool used for managing incoming requests could not be initialized. Typically, this results from an incorrectly configured web.config, such as missing handlers, invalid handler types, etc. If logging is configured, there will be additional details available in your logs.
member.remarks: The error text is: 610::The thread pool has not been initialized. Check your web.config handler settings.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.HandshakeFailure
member.summary: This error occurs when the client's attempt to connect to the server was denied. This could be for any number of reasons; check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 701::The handshake operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.InvalidConnectionType
member.summary: This error occurs when the client does not support any of the connection types supported by the server. This should never occur when using the signalling server in association with a signalling client. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 702::A common connection type could not be negotiated.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.ExlusiveConnect
member.summary: This error occurs when a streaming connection is opened to a handler that requires an exclusive session lock.
member.remarks: The error text is: 711::Streaming connections cannot be opened to a handler with an exclusive session lock.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.NoConnectionType
member.summary: This error occurs when a streaming connection has no connection type specified.
member.remarks: The error text is: 712::Streaming connections require a connection type.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.SubscribeFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that the client attempted to subscribe to a channel, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 721::The subscribe operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.PublishFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that a client attempted to send a publication to a channel, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 731::The publish operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.UnsubscribeFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that the client attempted to unsubscribe from a channel, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 741::The unsubscribe operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.DisconnectFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that the client attempted to disconnect from the server, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 751::The disconnect operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.BindFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that the client attempted to bind a key/value to itself, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 761::The bind operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.UnbindFailure
member.summary: This error indicates that the client attempted to unbind a key from itself, but failed. Check your server logs for details.
member.remarks: The error text is: 771::The unbind operation failed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.GenericBeforeEventFailed
member.summary: This error indicates that an error occurred or the request was flagged as unsuccessful in a `Before` event handler. A typical example of this would be authentication failure. The [Anything] represents the actual error text specified by the developer.
member.remarks: The error text is: 801::[Anything].

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.GenericAfterEventFailed
member.summary: This error indicates that an error occurred or the response was flagged as unsuccessful in an `After` event handler. This typically indicates a programming error, as successful responses should not be disguised as unsuccessful. The [Anything] represents the actual error text specified by the developer.
member.remarks: The error text is: 802::[Anything].

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.GenericSignallingException
member.summary: This error occurs when an unexpected exception occurs within signalling itself. If this error occurs, more details will be available in the logs (if configured). The [Anything] will contain the error messages from the source of the error. This should *never* be seen, so if you do, please contact us.
member.remarks: The error text is: 901::[Anything]

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.ErrorCode.GenericIISException
member.summary: This error occurs when an unexpected exception occurs within the request handling of IIS. If this error occurs, more details will be available in the logs (if configured). The [Anything] will contain the error messages from the source of the error.
member.remarks: The error text is: 901::[Anything]

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.EventType
member.summary: The signalling event type.

remarks.para: This enumeration describes all possible signalling server-side events triggered by clients, publishers, server-side methods, and the idling client detector. (See for descriptions of the sources that can trigger events.)
Event types can be combined using the bitwise OR (|) operator. This can be especially useful when using to define server-side event methods, as the same code can be used for multiple event types.
The following example illustrates combining event types in a single event method.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Provider
member.summary: Base definition of the methods required for a signalling provider implementation.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.Provider.PersistsClients
member.summary: Whether or not the signalling provider persists clients externally to the process. If this method returns false, then any pending HTTP requests will be ejected from the process when IIS starts to shut it down. Additionally, any clients in the sticky cache will be force-disconnected with appropriate unbind/unsubscribe/disconnect events. Defaults to true.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.RequestHandler
member.summary: HTTP handler that services Bayeux client/publisher requests.

remarks.para: This handler is intended to be the primary endpoint for all Bayeux clients and publishers that integrate with signalling. The path to the handler is specified by its registration in web.config (system.web/httpHandlers or system.webServer/handlers).
Several static methods on this class provide easy access to client and server manipulation - subscribing, publishing, binding, and retrieving statistics locally or globally.

It is possible to attach custom code to the request handling process. This allows the requests to be modified on their way to the server, and the responses to be modified on their way back to the source client/publisher. To start, simply declare a static method and decorate it with .
If HttpContext.Session data is required in custom code, use instead of this class in web.config. Note that the overhead associated with .NET session handling will decrease performance.
See below for an example of how to attach to the event and authenticate the request.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SignallingEventArgs.Forced
member.summary: Whether or not the event was forced by an external trigger and therefore ignores any changes to (cannot be cancelled).

remarks.para: This property is true under very specific conditions:

list.item: A client disconnecting with subscribed channels forces an implicit unsubscribe of those channels. If a disconnecting client was subscribed to any channels, then after with is fired, and with will be fired sequentially with this property set to true.

A client being disconnected due to idling forces a disconnect as well as an implicit unsubscribe of any subscribed channels. If an idling client was subscribed to any channels, , , , with will be fired sequentially with this property set to true. If an idling client was not subscribed to any channels, and will not fire.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SignallingEventAttribute
member.summary: Declares a static method to be invoked on events related to the processing of signalling requests.

remarks.para: Decorating a method with this attribute will cause it to attach to the specified and execute whenever that is raised. Decorated methods can be declared anywhere, but the recommended practice is to create a static containing class (i.e. SignallingEvents) that houses all decorated methods. If signalling is configured to run with targetedScan=true (see web.config options), then it is necessary to define the assembly-level for each class containing signalling event methods.

Use of this attribute is intended for application developers writing custom code as well as third-party signalling extension developers. When writing a third-party extension for distribution, defining is not optional.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Server.SignallingSecurityAttribute
member.summary: Used in conjunction with the , configures a signalling event to require authentication and optionally, one of a defined set of roles.

remarks.para: Decorating a method/class with this attribute will cause it to verify authentication before allowing access to the signalling event(s). If roles are specified, the currently logged-in user is allowed to proceed only if it belongs to one of the roles.

member.summary: The roles to which a user must belong for access.

member.summary: Gets or sets the user ID. The user ID can be set before connecting to the server to allow client events to be associated with a particular user.

member.summary: Gets or sets the device ID. The device ID can be set before connecting to the server to allow client events to be associated with a particular device.

member.summary: Gets or sets the number of milliseconds before the server takes action to discover if this client is idling or still active.

member.summary: Raised when the state changes.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.State
member.summary: Gets the state.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.StreamRequestUrl
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute URL of the signalling request handler for streaming connections, typically ending with sync.ashx.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.Synchronous
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to execute client methods synchronously. This approach is not recommended for UI threads, as it will block until the request completes. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.Token
member.summary: Gets or sets the token sent with each request for load balancing purposes.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.StreamRequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds to wait for a stream request to return a response before it is aborted and another stream request is attempted.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.DisableWebSockets
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to disable WebSocket protocol support and use long-polling, even if the server is capable of accepting WebSocket requests.

member.summary: Sets a callback to be invoked whenever messages are received on the specified channel.

remarks.para: This method does not subscribe you to a channel. Rather, it caches a callback to be executed when messages are received on a particular channel.

The callback to invoke when a message is received.

member.summary: Sets a callback to be invoked whenever messages are received on the specified channel. The tag allows multiple callbacks to be registered for the same channel.

remarks.para: This method does not subscribe you to a channel. Rather, it caches a callback to be executed when messages are received on a particular channel.

member.param: The channel over which the messages will be received.
The callback to invoke when a message is received.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.GetCustomOnReceive(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the callback invoked whenever messages are received on the specified channel.
member.param: The channel over which the messages are being received.
member.returns: The callback invoked when a message is received, if a callback is set; otherwise null.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.GetCustomOnReceiveWithTag(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the callback invoked whenever messages are received on the specified channel. The tag denotes a specific callback.
member.param: The channel over which the messages are being received.
member.returns: The callback invoked when a message is received, if a callback is set; otherwise null.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.UnsetCustomOnReceive(System.String)
member.summary: Unsets a callback invoked whenever messages are received on the specified channel.

remarks.para: This method does not unsubscribe you from a channel. Rather, it stops the callback from executing when messages are received on a particular channel.

member.returns: true if the callback was previously set; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.StartBatch
member.summary: Flags the start of a batch of requests to be sent together to the server.
member.remarks: This is used in conjunction with , which flags the end of a batch of requests and starts sending them to the server. Batching is used to optimize round-trips to the server by reducing the overhead associated with creating multiple HTTP requests.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.InBatch
member.summary: Gets whether or not requests are currently being batched.
member.returns: true if requests are being batched; otherwise false.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.Client.EndBatch
member.summary: Flags the end of a batch of requests and starts sending them to the server.
member.remarks: This is used in conjunction with , which must be called first to flag the start of a batch of requests to be sent together to the server. Batching is used to optimize round-trips to the server by reducing the overhead associated with creating multiple HTTP requests.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.RequestUrl
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute URL of the signalling request handler, typically ending with sync.ashx.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.RequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of milliseconds to wait for a standard request to return a response before it is aborted and another request is attempted. Defaults to 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.RequestMaxRetries
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of retries allowed for a standard request. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.DomainKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the domain key for sandboxing connections to the server. Defaults to "11111111-1111-1111-1111-111111111111".

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.DomainName
member.summary: Gets or sets the domain name to send as the Referrer with each request. Defaults to "localhost".

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.DisableBinary
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to disable the transmission of binary payloads as binary on the wire. If set to true, binary payloads will be sent over the wire as base64-encoded strings.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.ConcurrencyMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag indicating the level of concurrency in the current process. The intended use of this property is to lighten the processor load when hundreds or thousands of instances are created in a single process for the purposes of generating load for testing.

member.name: E:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.OnUnhandledException
member.summary: Raised when an exception is thrown in user code and not handled, typically in a callback or event handler.

member.name: E:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.OnRequestCreated
member.summary: Raised whenever a new request is created and about to be transferred to the server. This is a good place to read or modify outgoing messages.

member.name: E:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.OnResponseReceived
member.summary: Raised whenever a new response is received and about to be processed by the client. This is a good place to read or modify incoming messages.

member.name: E:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.OnHttpRequestCreated
member.summary: Raised whenever an underlying HTTP request has been created and is about to be transferred to the server. This is a good place to add headers/cookies. For WebSocket streams, this will fire only once for the initial HTTP-based handshake.

member.name: E:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.OnHttpResponseReceived
member.summary: Raised whenever an underlying HTTP response has been received and is about to be processed by the client. This is a good place to read headers/cookies. For WebSocket streams, this will fire only once for the initial HTTP-based handshake.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.InternalOnRequestCreated(FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.MessageRequestCreatedArgs)
member.summary: Wrapper for the event.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.ClientBase.InternalOnResponseReceived(FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.MessageResponseReceivedArgs)
member.summary: Wrapper for the event.

member.summary: Wrapper for the event.

member.summary: Wrapper for the event.

summary.para: Base class that defines the properties and methods shared by any class that is considered extensible by the Bayeux specification.

The Bayeux specification defines the Ext field, which allows custom data to be stored with a message using a namespaced key to access the information. This class provides methods that store and retrieve JSON data stored in this manner. For example, the property uses the Ext field to store its value using "fm.meta" as a key.

In addition, classes which inherit from can store dynamic property values for local read/write access without the need to serialize to JSON. This can aid greatly in the development of third-party extensions to signalling. Custom information can be stored with method arguments in the "before" event and read out again for further processing in the "after" event.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.InputArgs.Synchronous
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the request should be executed asynchronously. If true, the request will be executed synchronously. If false, the request will be executed asynchronously. If null, the request will be executed synchronously or asynchronously, depending on the value of Synchronous. Defaults to null.

member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke whenever a new request is created and about to be transferred to the server. This is a good place to read or modify outgoing messages.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.MessageRequestArgs.OnResponseReceived
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke whenever a new response is received and about to be processed by the client. This is a good place to read or modify incoming messages.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.MessageRequestArgs.OnHttpRequestCreated
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke whenever an underlying HTTP request has been created and is about to be transferred to the server. This is a good place to add headers/cookies. For WebSocket streams, this will fire only once for the initial HTTP-based handshake.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Signalling.MessageRequestArgs.OnHttpResponseReceived
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke whenever an underlying HTTP response has been received and is about to be processed by the client. This is a good place to read headers/cookies. For WebSocket streams, this will fire only once for the initial HTTP-based handshake.

summary.para: The signalling publisher, used for publishing data rapidly and efficiently.

remarks.para: When developing real-time applications, it is often most efficient and secure to publish data from a server, a web service, or in general, a source that doesn't require the ability to subscribe to channels. The is designed to do just that.

A common use case for the is to send out data as it arrives from a real-time feed (e.g. stock data, sports scores, news articles, etc.). Wherever the feed is located, the can be used to send out the data rapidly to any subscribed clients.
For security reasons, signalling Server blocks Publisher requests by default. To enable direct publication, make sure "allowPublishers" is enabled in web.config.
The publisher always runs synchronously.

example.para: Here's a simple example of how to create a publisher in C# and publish some data.

remarks.para: There are multiple overloads for the "Publish" method. For batch publications, use the overloads that take a collection of Publications. They will be automatically batched and delivered in a single round-trip.

member.summary: Indicates that all connectivity checks have timed out or produced a failure response.

member.summary: Indicates that connectivity checks have been stopped intentionally due to transport closure.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidatePairState.ConnectivityLost
member.summary: Indicates that connectivity checks have succeeded in the past, but are currently not responding.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType
member.summary: The type of a candidate.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType.Host
member.summary: Indicates a 'host' candidate, discovered by querying a local network interface adapter. The candidate should contain a private IP address of this client.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType.ServerReflexive
member.summary: Indicates a 'srflx' candidate, discovered by using a STUN server to echo back the source IP address it sees in a UDP binding request. When the STUN server is properly configured, the candidate should contain a public IP address of this client.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType.Relayed
member.summary: Indicates a 'relay' candidate, discovered by using a TURN server to set up a public port in response to a UDP or TCP allocate request. When the TURN server is properly configured, the candidate should contain a public IP address of the TURN server.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType.PeerReflexive
member.summary: Indicates a 'prflx' candidate, discovered by sending STUN connectivity checks between peers residing behind more restrictive firewalls. The candidate should contain a public IP address of this client.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.CandidateType.Unknown
member.summary: Indicates an unknown candidate type.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.LayoutScale
member.summary: Specifies how an element should be scaled within a layout.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.LayoutScale.Contain
member.summary: Indicates that the element should be uniformly scaled (maintaining aspect ratio) to the largest size such that both its width and its height can fit inside its bounding box.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.LayoutScale.Cover
member.summary: Indicates that the element should be uniformly scaled (maintaining aspect ratio) to be as large as possible so that the bounding box is completely covered. Some parts of the element may not be in view (cropped).

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.LayoutScale.Stretch
member.summary: Indicates that the element should be non-uniformly scaled (not maintaining aspect ratio) so that the bounding box is completely covered, but all parts of the element are in view (no cropping).

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory
member.summary: Specified Multiplexing category of SDP Attribute. Rules governing SDP Attribute multiplexing are as per draft-ietf-mmusic-sdp-mux-attributes

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Normal
member.summary: The attributes in the NORMAL category can be independently specified when multiplexed and they retain their original semantics.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Caution
member.summary: The attributes in the CAUTION category are advised against multiplexing since their usage under multiplexing might lead to incorrect behaviour.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Identical
member.summary: The attributes and their associated values (if any) in the IDENTICAL category MUST be repeated across all the media descriptions under multiplexing.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Sum
member.summary: The attributes in the SUM category can be set as they are normally used but software using them in the multiplexing scenario MUST apply the sum of all the attributes being multiplexed instead of trying to use them independently.This is typically used for bandwidth or other rate limiting attributes to the underlying transport.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Transport
member.summary: The attributes in the TRANSPORT category can be set normally for multiple items in a multiplexed group but the software MUST pick the one that's associated with the "m=" line whose information is used for setting up the underlying transport.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Inherit
member.summary:
The attributes in the INHERIT category encapsulate other SDP attributes or parameters. These attributes inherit their multiplexing characteristics from the attributes or parameters they encapsulate. Such attributes are defined in [RFC3407], [RFC5939] and [RFC6871] as part of a generic framework for indicating and negotiating transport, media, and media format related capabilities in the SDP.
The inheritance manifests itself when the encapsulated attribute or parameter is being leveraged. In the case of SDP Capability Negotiation [RFC5939] for example, this occurs when a capability (encapsulating attribute) is used as part of a configuration; the configuration inherits the multiplexing category of each of its constituent (encapsulated) attributes and parameters. The inherited attributes MUST be coherent in order to form a valid configuration from a multiplexing point of view (see Section 14 for further details).

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.IdenticalPerPT
member.summary: The attributes in the IDENTICAL-PER-PT category define the RTP payload configuration on per Payload Type basis and MUST have identical values across all the media descriptions for a given RTP Payload Type when repeated. These Payload Types identify the same codec configuration as defined in the Section 10.1.2 of [I-D.ietf-mmusic-sdp-bundle-negotiation] under this context.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.AttributeCategory.Special
member.summary: For the attributes in the SPECIAL category, the text in the specification defining the attribute MUST be consulted for further handling when multiplexed.

member.summary:
Defined in draft-ietf-mmusic-sdp-bundle-negotiation. Attribute is used to identify that a gioven media description can only be used in bundled group. Its formatting in SDP is described by the following BNF: Name: bundle-only
Value: N/A
Usage Level: media
Charset Dependent: no
Example:
a=bundle-only

member.summary:
This specifies the character set to be used to display the session name and information data. By default, the ISO-10646 character set in UTF-8 encoding is used. If a more compact representation is required, other character sets may be used. For example, the ISO 8859-1 is specified with the following SDP attribute:
a=charset:ISO-8859-1

member.summary: Gets the SDP conference type meaning "Moderated", which should indicate the use of a floor control tool and that the media tools are started so as to mute new sites joining the conference.

member.summary: Gets the SDP conference type meaning "Test", which should imply that unless explicitly requested otherwise, receivers can safely avoid displaying this session description to users.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.ConferenceType.H332
member.summary: Gets the SDP conference type meaning "H332", which should imply receive-only and indicate that this loosely coupled session is part of an H.332 session.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.ConferenceTypeAttribute
member.summary: This specifies the type of the conference. Suggested values are "broadcast", "meeting", "moderated", "test", and "H332". "recvonly" should be the default for "type:broadcast" sessions, "type:meeting" should imply "sendrecv", and "type:moderated" should indicate the use of a floor control tool and that the media tools are started so as to mute new sites joining the conference.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.CryptoAttribute
member.summary: This gives the maximum amount of media that can be encapsulated in each packet, expressed as time in milliseconds. The time SHALL be calculated as the sum of the time the media present in the packet represents. For frame-based codecs, the time SHOULD be an integer multiple of the frame size. This attribute is probably only meaningful for audio data, but may be used with other media types if it makes sense. It is a media-level attribute, and it is not dependent on charset. Note that this attribute was introduced after RFC 2327, and non-updated implementations will ignore this attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.FormatParametersAttribute
member.summary: This attribute allows parameters that are specific to a particular format to be conveyed in a way that SDP does not have to understand them. The format must be one of the formats specified for the media. Format-specific parameters may be any set of parameters required to be conveyed by SDP and given unchanged to the media tool that will use this format. At most one instance of this attribute is allowed for each format.

member.summary: This gives the maximum video frame rate in frames/sec. It is intended as a recommendation for the encoding of video data. Decimal representations of fractional values using the notation "integer.fraction" are allowed. It is a media-level attribute, defined only for video media, and it is not dependent on charset.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.GroupSemanticsType
member.summary: SDP Group Semantics

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.GroupSemanticsType.LipSynchronization
member.summary: An application that receives a session description that contains "m" lines that are grouped together using LS semantics MUST synchronize the playout of the corresponding media streams.Note that LS semantics not only apply to a video stream that has to be synchronized with an audio stream.The playout of two streams of the same type can be synchronized as well.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.GroupSemanticsType.FlowIdentification
member.summary: An "m" line in an SDP session description defines a media stream. However, SDP does not define what a media stream is. This definition can be found in the RTSP specification.The RTSP RFC[5] defines a media stream as "a single media instance, e.g., an audio stream or a video stream as well as a single whiteboard or shared application group. When using RTP, a stream consists of all RTP and RTCP packets created by a source within an RTP session".

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.GroupSemanticsType.Bundling
member.summary: The extension can be used with the Session Description Protocol(SDP) Offer/Answer mechanism[RFC3264] to negotiate which "m=" sections will become part of a BUNDLE group.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.GroupSemanticsType.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown Group semantics type.

member.summary: The attribute contains a connection-address and port for each component. The ordering of components is irrelevant. However, a value MUST be present for each component of a media stream. This attribute MUST be included in an offer by a controlling agent for a media stream that is Completed, and MUST NOT be included in any other case.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.InactiveAttribute
member.summary: This specifies that the tools should be started in inactive mode. This is necessary for interactive conferences where users can put other users on hold. No media is sent over an inactive media stream. Note that an RTP-based system SHOULD still send RTCP, even if started inactive. It can be either a session or media-level attribute, and it is not dependent on charset.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets the internal value of the attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.KeywordsAttribute
member.summary: Like the cat attribute, this is to assist identifying wanted sessions at the receiver. This allows a receiver to select interesting session based on keywords describing the purpose of the session; there is no central registry of keywords. It is a session-level attribute. It is a charset-dependent attribute, meaning that its value should be interpreted in the charset specified for the session description if one is specified, or by default in ISO 10646/UTF-8.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.KeywordsAttribute.Keywords
member.summary: Gets or sets the keywords describing the purpose of the session.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The keywords describing the purpose of the session.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.KeywordsAttribute.GetAttributeValue
member.summary: Gets the internal value of the attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.LanguageAttribute
member.summary: This can be a session-level attribute or a media-level attribute. As a session-level attribute, it specifies the default language for the session being described. As a media- level attribute, it specifies the language for that media, overriding any session-level language specified. Multiple lang attributes can be provided either at session or media level if the session description or media use multiple languages, in which case the order of the attributes indicates the order of importance of the various languages in the session or media from most important to least important.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.LanguageAttribute.LanguageTag
member.summary: Gets or sets the default language for the session being described (if used as a session-level attribute) or the language for a media stream (if used as a media-level attribute).

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The default language for the session being described (if used as a session-level attribute) or the language for a media stream (if used as a media-level attribute).

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.LanguageAttribute.GetAttributeValue
member.summary: Gets the internal value of the attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MaxPacketTimeAttribute
member.summary: This gives the maximum amount of media that can be encapsulated in each packet, expressed as time in milliseconds. The time SHALL be calculated as the sum of the time the media present in the packet represents. For frame-based codecs, the time SHOULD be an integer multiple of the frame size. This attribute is probably only meaningful for audio data, but may be used with other media types if it makes sense. It is a media-level attribute, and it is not dependent on charset. Note that this attribute was introduced after RFC 2327, and non-updated implementations will ignore this attribute.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MaxPacketTimeAttribute.MaxPacketTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum amount of media that can be encapsulated, in each packet, expressed as time in milliseconds.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MediaStreamIdAttribute
member.summary:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5888#page-4 "Media stream identification" media attribute, which is used for identifying media streams within a session description. Its formatting in SDP [RFC4566] is described by the following Augmented Backus-Naur Form(ABNF) [RFC5234]:
mid-attribute = "a=mid:" identification-tag identification-tag = token ; token is defined in RFC 4566 The identification-tag MUST be unique within an SDP session description.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MediaStreamIdAttribute.IdentificationTag
member.summary: Gets the identification tag.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets the internal value of the attribute.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MediaStreamIdSemanticAttribute
member.summary:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-mmusic-msid-08 - NB: Removed in subsequent drafts, most likely will not be used eventually. Used here for compatibility with Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox.
A session-level attribute is defined for signalling the semantics associated with an msid grouping.This allows msid groupings with different semantics to coexist.
This OPTIONAL attribute gives the group identifier and its group semantic; it carries the same meaning as the ssrc-group-attr of RFC 5576 section 4.2, but uses the identifier of the group rather than a list of SSRC values.
This attribute MUST be present if "a=msid" is used.
An empty list of identifiers is an indication that the sender supports the indicated semantic, but has no msid groupings of the given type in the present SDP.
An identifier of "*" is an indication that all "a=msid" lines in the SDP have this specific semantic. If "*" is not used, each msid-id in the SDP MUST appear in one and only one "msid-semantic" line. The name of the attribute is "msid-semantic". The value of the attribute is given by the following ABNF:
msid-semantic-value = msid - semantic msid-list msid-semantic = token ; see RFC 4566 msid-list = *(" " msid-id) / " *"
The semantic field holds values from the IANA registriy "Semantics for the msid-semantic SDP attribute" (which is defined in Section 6 of https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-mmusic-msid-08 ).
An example msid-semantic might look like this, if a semantic LS was registered by IANA for the same purpose as the existing LS grouping semantic:
a= msid-semantic:LS xyzzy forolow
This means that the SDP description has two lip sync groups, with the group identifiers xyzzy and forolow, respectively.
The msid-semantic attribute can occur more than once, but MUST NOT occur more than once with the same msid-semantic value.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.MediaStreamIdSemanticAttribute.MsIdList
member.summary:
Gets or sets the space-delimited list of msids for which a given semantic is used. An empty list of identifiers is an indication that the sender supports the indicated semantic, but has no msid groupings of the given type in the present SDP.
An identifier of "*" is an indication that all "a=msid" lines in the SDP have this specific semantic. If "*" is not used, each msid-id in the SDP MUST appear in one and only one "msid-semantic" line.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.PacketTimeAttribute
member.summary: This gives the length of time in milliseconds represented by the media in a packet. This is probably only meaningful for audio data, but may be used with other media types if it makes sense. It should not be necessary to know ptime to decode RTP or vat audio, and it is intended as a recommendation for the encoding/packetisation of audio. It is a media-level attribute, and it is not dependent on charset.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.QualityAttribute
member.summary:
This gives a suggestion for the quality of the encoding as an integer value. The intention of the quality attribute for video is to specify a non-default trade-off between frame-rate and still-image quality. For video, the value is in the range 0 to 10, with the following suggested meaning:
10 - the best still-image quality the compression scheme can give. 5 - the default behaviour given no quality suggestion. 0 - the worst still-image quality the codec designer thinks is still usable.
It is a media-level attribute, and it is not dependent on charset.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.QualityAttribute.Quality
member.summary: Gets or sets the suggested quality of the encoding as an integer value from 0-10.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The suggested quality of the encoding as an integer value from 0-10.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.ExtMapAttribute
member.summary:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5285#section-5 Stream or media-level attribute used to indicate the presence of RTP Header Extensions, and the mapping of local identifiers used in the header extension to a larger namespace.
A usable mapping MUST use IDs in the valid range, and each ID in this range MUST be used only once for each media (or only once if the mappings are session level). Mappings that do not conform to these rules MAY be presented, for instance, during offer/answer negotiation as described in the next section, but remapping to conformant values is necessary before they can be applied.
Each extension is named by a URI. Each local identifier potentially used in the stream is mapped to a string using an attribute of the form: a=extmap:VALUE["/"DIRECTION] URI EXTENSIONATTRIBUTES Where URI is a URI, as above, VALUE is the local identifier (ID) of this extension and is an integer in the valid range inclusive (0 is reserved for padding in both forms, and 15 is reserved in the one-byte header form), and direction is one of "sendonly", "recvonly", "sendrecv", or "inactive" (without the quotes). Example:
a=extmap:1 http://example.com/082005/ext.htm#ttime a=extmap:2/sendrecv http://example.com/082005/ext.htm#xmeta short

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.ExtMapAttribute.Id
member.summary: Gets or sets the local identifier of this extension.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.ExtMapAttribute.Uri
member.summary: Gets the well-known URI of this extension

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.ExtMapAttribute.ExtensionAttributes
member.summary: Gets or sets extension attributes (optional).

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.ExtMapAttribute.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the direction of this extension (optional). If not present, stream direction is assumed to be the direction of the extension.

member.summary: RTP Extension Map Attribute.
member.param: Local identifier of this extension and is an integer in the valid range inclusive (0 is reserved for padding in both forms, and 15 is reserved in the one-byte header form.

member.summary: RTP Extension Map Attribute.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction
member.summary: A restriction for an RID attribute.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxWidthKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-width" key, for spatial resolution in pixels. In the case that stream orientation signaling is used to modify the intended display orientation, this attribute refers to the width of the stream when a rotation of zero degrees is encoded.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxHeightKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-height" key, for spatial resolution in pixels. In the case that stream orientation signaling is used to modify the intended display orientation, this attribute refers to the height of the stream when a rotation of zero degrees is encoded.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxFramesPerSecondKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-fps" key, for frame rate in frames per second. For encoders that do not use a fixed framerate for encoding, this value is used to restrict the minimum amount of time between frames: the time between any two consecutive frames SHOULD NOT be less than 1 / max - fps seconds.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxFrameSizeKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-fs" key, for frame size in pixels per frame. This is the product of frame width and frame height, in pixels, for rectangular frames.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxBitrateKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-br" key, for bit rate in bits per second. The restriction applies to the media payload only, and does not include overhead introduced by other layers(e.g., RTP, UDP, IP, or Ethernet). The exact means of keeping within this limit are left up to the implementation, and instantaneous excursions outside the limit are permissible. For any given one-second sliding window, however, the total number of bits in the payload portion of RTP SHOULD NOT exceed the value specified in "max-br."

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxPixelsPerSecondKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-pps" key, for pixel rate in pixels per second. This value SHOULD be handled identically to max-fps, after performing the following conversion: max-fps = max-pps / (width* height). If the stream resolution changes, this value is recalculated. Due to this recalculation, excursions outside the specified maximum are possible near resolution change boundaries.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.MaxBitsPerPixelKey
member.summary: Gets the "max-bpp" key, for maximum number of bits per pixel, calculated as an average of all samples of any given coded picture. This is expressed as a floating point value, with an allowed range of 0.0001 to 48.0. These values MUST NOT be encoded with more than four digits to the right of the decimal point.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.DependKey
member.summary: Gets the "depend" key, for spatial resolution in pixels. The value is a comma-separated list of rid-ids.These rid-ids identify RTP streams that this stream depends on in order to allow for proper interpretation. The mechanism defined in this document allows for such dependencies to be expressed only when the streams are in the same media section.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.Key
member.summary: Gets the restriction key.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Rtp.RidRestriction.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the restriction value.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.Sctp.MapAttribute
member.summary: AB: Legacy attribute. To be removed when Firefox and Chrome stop using it. The sctpmap attribute maps from a port number (as used in an "m=" line) to an encoding name denoting the payload format to be used on top of the SCTP association or the actual protocol running on top of it. Last appears in https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-mmusic-sctp-sdp-06#page-6 Has been replaced in subsequent drafts but is used in Firefox and Chrome for now.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.SdpLanguageAttribute
member.summary: This can be a session-level attribute or a media-level attribute. As a session-level attribute, it specifies the language for the session description. As a media-level attribute, it specifies the language for any media-level SDP information field associated with that media. Multiple sdplang attributes can be provided either at session or media level if multiple languages in the session description or media use multiple languages, in which case the order of the attributes indicates the order of importance of the various languages in the session or media from most important to least important.

member.name: P:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.SdpLanguageAttribute.LanguageTag
member.summary: Gets or sets the language for either the session description (if used as a session-level attribute) or any media-level SDP information field associated with that media (if used as a media-level attribute).

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.Sdp.SendOnlyAttribute
member.summary: This specifies that the tools should be started in send-only mode. An example may be where a different unicast address is to be used for a traffic destination than for a traffic source. In such a case, two media descriptions may be used, one sendonly and one recvonly. It can be either a session- or media-level attribute, but would normally only be used as a media attribute. It is not dependent on charset. Note that sendonly applies only to the media, and any associated control protocol (e.g., RTCP) SHOULD still be received and processed as normal.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState
member.summary: The invite feedback states.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Unknown
member.summary: Gets the unknown state.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Pending
member.summary: Gets the state for "pending". This state is for when no feedback has been received yet.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Proceeding
member.summary: Gets the state for "proceeding". This state is for when we are waiting for the invited party to respond.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Sent
member.summary: Gets the state for "sent". This state is for when the invite is sent in a way that does not allow feedback to be returned.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Cancelled
member.summary: Gets the state for "canceled". This state is for when the invite has been canceled.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Cancelling
member.summary: Gets the state for "cancelling". This state is for when the invite is in the process of being cancelled. May fail due to timing.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Rejected
member.summary: Gets the state for "rejected". This state is for when the invitation was explicitly rejected.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Accepted
member.summary: Gets the state for "accepted". This state is for when the invitation was accepted.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.NotFound
member.summary: Gets the state for "notFound". This state is for when the invited user id cannot be found.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Busy
member.summary: Gets the state for "busy". This state is for when the invited user signals they are busy.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.NoResponse
member.summary: Gets the state for "noResponse". This state is for when the invitation did not receive a response.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.Invalid
member.summary: Gets the state for "invalid". This state is when the invitation cannot be processed.

member.name: F:FM.LiveSwitch.InvitationState.AlreadyInvited
member.summary: Gets the state for "alreadyInvited". This state is when another invite for the same user id, protocol, and channel already exists.
